channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SOLR-16295] Modernize and Standardize Solr description across all platforms
item.description:
Currently everywhere we have a page on "Solr", we have a short description on what the project/product is. They are all roughly the same, but we should try to improve this language and standardize it everywhere.

The places I can think of currently are:

  • solr.apache.org
  • Ref Guide
  • Github - Solr
  • DockerHub - Solr
  • ArtifactHub - Solr

The Solr Operator pages don't really give a Solr description, which is fine.

Please comment if I forgot any, so that we can have a comprehensive list.

Once we agree on the standardized language, we can then update it everywhere it needs to go (since the above list are managed in a variety of places).
item.summary: Modernize and Standardize Solr description across all platforms

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Chatting with houston we came up with:

Solr is the popular, blazing fast open source search platform for all your
enterprise, e-commerce, and analytics needs, built on [Apache Lucene](https://lucene.apache.org/).

Also mentions in solr git repo

  • README.md
  • doap file (powers e.g. https://projects.apache.org/project.html?solr)
  • releaseWizard.yaml
  • Documentation site template, generating index.html for e.g. https://solr.apache.org/docs/9_0_0/

Openhub.net: https://openhub.net/p/solr

Great....

So... How do we want to get consensus? Leave this ticket open for another few days, and then do we go with the slogan that I posted?
minor word smithing maybe: "search server" rather than "search platform" - platform seems to imply a full system from source docs to query. Just sounds a tad oversold to me.
I can go with that.... Until streaming expressions replaces spark etc Or until we have a true ML model develop/deploy pipeline in Solr....

I prefer the "platform" over "server". Solr has more than just index and query. There's:

  • The prometheus exporter (which is more than just solr-metrics)
  • Backup support for multiple repository types
  • The Solr Operator to manage Cloud deployments
  • In solr-sandbox, there's cross-datacenter support being worked on

"Search server" sounds a bit old as well. This is marketing, and "Search platform" looks much more modern to me.
"Search server platform"?  I also feel that "platform" is entirely appropriate.  It also may indicate it's not a turn-key product to make your website/DB searchable.
I tried saying "Search server platform" a bunch of times, and it felt awkward... The ambitious part of me really would like to see us be a platform for great search...

To me "platform" without "server" qualifier would involve us having a production ready system for getting arbitrary documents/data in as well as out. Right now, we have great features for serving, and several ways to input data in a formats that only very very rarely are 1:1 with the user's native format unless they designed the upstream system with Solr in mind. Thus users have very little to do to get results out, but a lot of work to do to get documents in. DIH and SolrCell were in the platform direction but we regularly identify these as not supported, not production ready or not good for non-trivial use cases.

If you're ambitious, come poke at JesterJ and tell me what's good/bad about it. (or fix stuff). if it became popular on it's own I'd have no issue with it being a related project or even donating it to the project (though I see that as an unlikely path due to small code overlap). Back in the very early days I called it "SolrSystem" (which would have run afoul of trademarks) with the idea of it being a one-touch install that provided document ingestion, and search serving in a tomcat container (back when we were a .war file). I've narrowed the scope to document ingestion since then, and recognize the need to have ingestion on separate hardware for non-trivial use cases of course, but the lack of a good, standard solution to put arbitrary documents into solr is something I've felt for almost a decade now. 

Anyway just my 0.02... I certainly won't object further whichever way this naming goes.

To me "platform" without "server" qualifier would involve us having a production ready system for getting arbitrary documents/data in as well as out

[Emphasis/bolding mine]

Just my two cents, but IMO "Search platform" as a phrase implies the out without implying anything about the in. It's not claiming "ETL and Search Platform" or "Ingestion and Search Platform"...only "Search Platform", which seems accurate to me.

I also agree with Houston's point that Solr is a lot more than just the "server" component.

Anyway, +1 to Eric's wording from me.

Reviving this discussion following some recent interest triggered by the looming 9.7 release. (See dev@ thread for details.). In particular, Anshum pointed out our website blurb, etc. doesn't highlight vector search.

With that in mind, what do folks think about the revised blurb below?

Solr is the blazing fast, open source, multi-modal search platform built on Apache Lucene. Supporting full-text, vector, faceted, and geospatial search, Solr meets the enterprise, e-commerce, and analytic-search needs of the world's largest organizations, apps, and websites.

We could optionally append an "Other features include..." sentence at the end of this blurb in places like the release announcements that have the "real estate" for extended description.

+1 to your blurb Jason.

Q: what is "multi-modal" as you mean it here? If it's a reference to users might be on mobile or on a desktop, I don't think that's relevant to this layer of an implementation stack.

No, I wasn't meaning mobile vs. desktop. I'm using it to refer to Solr's support for a handful of different "types" of searches: text search, vector search, geo search, graph search even, etc. My broader intention is to convey the idea that "Solr's not 'just' text search, it does all this other stuff as well"

Open to replacement words there, if "multimodal" is too confusing or has connotations with mobile/desktop, etc. (though I've always heard that called "form factor"). Lmk!

dsmiley
Since your blurb already calls out some of those, then multi-modal is redundant. (in addition to ambiguous)

I see your point and have removed it from the various PRs.

Will aim to merge and close this out in another day or two. The 9.7 re-spin has delayed things just enough that we can have this ready for the 9.7 announcement/release, which is awesome!

I really think that we need to call out 'multi-modal' here. The rationale behind this being that users are looking for that keyword without deep understanding of what it means. Without the keyword, it'll be tough for them to find us and try out Solr for their use case.

I'm ambivalent on "multi-modal" - I get that people search for it, but it's only one of many popular terms in that regard. (I'd guess "hybrid search" is at least as popular, for instance.) And we have to use some discretion - we can't include every relevant term without turning our project description into a Craigslist-style word salad.

But, on the other hand, this is the second vote for "multi-modal". Epugh mentioned liking it on one of the PRs. So I'll bring it back this morning and then look to merge things. We can always refine things later if a clearer consensus emerges on any of these wording points.

Commit 2d2b061b5710131e86c4a7ef48ab47960717651d in solr's branch refs/heads/main from Jason Gerlowski
[ https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=solr.git;h=2d2b061b571 ]

SOLR-16295: Modernize and standardize project description (#2692)

See JIRA for motivation and discussion of particular descriptors.

Commit daf0738f2f2075171da3d3f4e23a5517feaa3966 in solr's branch refs/heads/branch_9x from Jason Gerlowski
[ https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=solr.git;h=daf0738f2f2 ]

SOLR-16295: Modernize and standardize project description (#2692)

See JIRA for motivation and discussion of particular descriptors.

I've merged the PRs against the "solr", "solr-operator", "solr-site", and "solr-docker" repos. The only piece of this remaining is a PR with the docker-library folks to update our description there. They seem pretty responsive, so hopefully that'll be merged/reviewed in short order and we can close this ticket out.

Thanks all for the feedback and direction!

Closing this out, as the last (dockerhub) PR has been merged!

Not totally sure what to put as a "Fix Version" here, as many of the changes in this JIRA aren't tied to a versioned artifact, but I ended up going with 9.7 as this did change some README's that will ship in our 9.7 artifacts.
Closing after the 9.7.0 release
